modules.description: This module defines named schemes for approximating fundamental mathematical operations—such as exponentiation, logarithms, roots, trigonometric functions (e.g., `sin`, `cos`), and hyperbolic variants (e.g., `sinh`, `cosh`)—using table-based methods. These operations are represented as values of the `'a Scheme.t` type, enabling generic numeric computations while maintaining a consistent naming convention. It is particularly useful in numerical analysis or performance-sensitive contexts where precise, efficient approximations of standard math library functions are required.

This module approximates floating-point operations using table-based methods, supporting configurable rank polynomials and memory-backed coefficient storage. It operates on floating-point values and bitvectors, enabling concrete use cases like approximating transcendental functions (e.g., sine, cosine) with precomputed tables for performance-critical applications. The child module defines named schemes for fundamental operations—such as exponentiation, logarithms, roots, and trigonometric functions—represented as values of the `'a Scheme.t` type, enabling generic numeric computations. These schemes allow efficient, precise approximations of standard math functions in numerical analysis or performance-sensitive contexts.

This module approximates floating-point operations using table-based methods with configurable rank polynomials and memory-backed coefficient storage. It supports operations on floating-point values and bitvectors, enabling precise and efficient approximations of transcendental functions like sine, cosine, exponentials, and logarithms through precomputed tables. The core abstraction is the `'a Scheme.t` type, which represents named approximation schemes for fundamental mathematical operations. For example, users can apply a preconfigured sine approximation scheme to compute values with controlled precision or define custom polynomial-based approximations for domain-specific numerical tasks.
